comment.author: 46092965@N08
comment._content: Well, even though this is obviously a composite of two separate photographs, it does not in any way detract from this lovely composition.  Two  photographs combined artistically portray a great moment in American history.  I love it.

comment.author: 27043746@N03
comment._content:
I'd like the fakeboys to name one artefact in this shot that marks it as a fake.   If you are going to discredit the work of other photographers, have evidence.

This is a superb 'one-shot' shot.   The photog. probably spent days planning this one out.

comment._content: "Photoshop"?? LOL Please keep your idiotic thoughts to yourself... Thanks! grin.hq.nasa.gov/IMAGES/LARGE/GPN-2000-000627.jpg

comment.author: 44494372@N05
comment._content:
Please be respectful to each other, guys.  

I've asked some folks to look into this and see if we can get any additional info on the photo.  I'll post here as soon as I know anything more.

comment.author: 44494372@N05
comment._content: The awesome folks out at KSC came back with additional information, from a caption that was directly with the negative: The American flag heralds the flight of Apollo 11. Man’s first lunar landing mission. The photograph was taken from Cape Kennedy, adjacent to Kennedy Space Center where Apollo 11 lifted off from Pad 39A at 9:32 a.m. EDT. This image was imposed upon the image of the flag filmed a day earlier. 7/16/1969.

comment.author: 33775149@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nasacommons]  Thank you for clarifying the argument with this picture.

comment.author: 27043746@N03
comment._content: Thanks for clarifying that NASA.  If you're posting pictures of record, you should flag those that are manipulated or composites.

comment._content: It is also obivious if you look at the angle/height of the Saturn V in comparison to the possible height of the flag. In this picture the Saturn would be too low to be already at mach 1 speed and too much inclined from the vertical
